file_metadata.title: The Bioelectrics of Immortality and Mortality in Cold-Sensitive Hydra oligactis

chunks.text: Bioelectric properties are crucial in development, regeneration, and cancer, and are hypothesized to play a role in aging. This study investigates whole-body bioelectric patterns in immortal (22°C) and aging mortal (10°C) Hydra oligactis using voltage-sensitive dyes.  A consistent bioelectric atlas was established for immortal hydra, revealing a depolarized foot and occasionally depolarized tentacles. Immortal hydra exhibited greater overall depolarization and less sharply defined patterns compared to older, mortal hydra.  These findings establish hydra as a model for whole-body bioelectric imaging and suggest a bioelectric component to aging, potentially opening avenues for anti-aging therapies using electroceuticals.
chunks.chunk_summary: Immortal and aging Hydra exhibit distinct bioelectric patterns, with immortal hydra being more depolarized and less sharp, suggesting a link between bioelectricity and aging.

chunks.text: Aging presents fundamental questions in biology regarding the maintenance of form and function against disorder.  Bioelectric gradients of resting potential are crucial for maintaining tissue organization, and their degradation is hypothesized to contribute to aging.  While bioelectricity's role in development, regeneration, and cancer is established, large-scale bioelectric profiles during aging are lacking.  This study aims to establish such a dataset in hydra, a model relevant for aging research, to facilitate the development of electroceuticals for longevity and other bioelectricity-based anti-aging approaches.
chunks.chunk_summary: The degradation of bioelectric information may contribute to aging, and studying bioelectric profiles in model organisms like hydra can aid in developing anti-aging therapies.

chunks.text: Hydra are freshwater invertebrates with endodermal and ectodermal tissues, capable of sexual and asexual reproduction.  They serve as models for development, regeneration, transplantation, tumor biology, neural and muscle activity, and aging research.  Their transparency allows for whole-body imaging of cellular membrane voltage using voltage-sensitive dyes. Cold-sensitive (CS) Hydra oligactis are immortal at 22°C but age and die at 10°C, exhibiting age-related physiological declines.  This study investigates the hypothesis that bioelectric patterns exist in hydra and change with aging, becoming less crisp and more diffuse, with aging hydra predicted to be more hyperpolarized.
chunks.topic: Hydra as a model for aging
chunks.chunk_summary: Hydra's transparency and temperature-dependent aging make them an ideal model for studying bioelectric changes during aging.

chunks.text: The study details the methods for hydra husbandry, shrimp maintenance, aging induction, and dye-based imaging.  Hydra were grown at 22°C (immortal) and 10°C (aging) and imaged at specific intervals.  The imaging protocol involved using FluoVolt dye, Neuro Background Suppressor, and a confocal microscope with specific settings for image acquisition.  Image analysis was performed using ImageJ and custom scripts to quantify mean lifetime intensity, bioelectric sharpness (Moran's I), and foot-to-central body ratio.  Statistical analyses were conducted in R using ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis, and Wilcoxon rank sum tests.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study used a detailed protocol involving voltage-sensitive dyes, confocal microscopy, and image analysis to quantify bioelectric patterns in immortal and aging hydra.

chunks.text: Voltage-sensitive dyes revealed the relative membrane voltage of every cell in live immortal and mortal hydra, demonstrating the feasibility of whole-body bioelectric atlas generation.  Comparison of FluoVolt and VF2.1.Cl (voltage-sensitive) with VF2.0.Cl (voltage-insensitive) confirmed that the observed signals reflected membrane voltage and not artifacts.  Immortal hydra exhibited a consistently depolarized foot and occasionally depolarized tentacles, while other regions showed variable voltage.  Aging was confirmed in hydra grown at 10°C by the presence of ovaries/testes.  Old mortal hydra were more hyperpolarized and bioelectrically sharper overall than immortal hydra, but the foot-to-central body ratio was less sharp in old mortal hydra.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study successfully imaged whole-body bioelectric patterns in hydra, confirming voltage-dependent dye responses and revealing distinct patterns in immortal and aging hydra, with aging associated with hyperpolarization and altered sharpness.

chunks.text: This study establishes a whole-body bioelectric atlas for immortal and aging Hydra, confirming aging at 10°C via gametogenesis.  The use of a voltage-insensitive control dye validated the voltage-dependent responses of FluoVolt and VF2.1.Cl.  This study represents the first report of whole-body bioelectric imaging in living organisms, enabled by hydra's transparency and advances in voltage-sensitive dyes and FLIM.  The depolarized foot and tentacles in immortal hydra may relate to adhesive and secretory functions, respectively.  Variability in bioelectric patterns was observed across individuals, with interindividual variation exceeding intraindividual variation.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study generated a whole-body bioelectric atlas of hydra, validating dye responses and highlighting interindividual variability in bioelectric patterns.

chunks.text: Old mortal hydra exhibited a more hyperpolarized bioelectric pattern overall compared to immortal hydra, potentially due to dysregulation of depolarization in secretory cells, decreased interstitial stem cells (which are typically depolarized), and potential links between hyperpolarization and disrupted actin fibers observed in aging hydra.  The relationship between polarization and aging varies across organisms and cell types.  The sharpness of bioelectric patterns, which is disrupted in developmental defects, was also altered in aging hydra, with increased overall sharpness but decreased sharpness in the foot-to-central body ratio, suggesting region-specific effects of aging on bioelectric pattern crispness.
chunks.chunk_summary: Aging hydra exhibited hyperpolarization, potentially linked to decreased stem cells and disrupted actin fibers, while the sharpness of bioelectric patterns showed region-specific changes.

chunks.text: Future studies should investigate the mechanisms underlying the observed bioelectric patterns in hydra, including the roles of ion channels and pumps, cell-specific coordination of voltage changes, and the relationship between bioelectric patterns and age-related physiological changes.  Transgenic hydra and optogenetics could be used to explore the causal role of bioelectricity in morphogenesis and aging.  The study's findings pave the way for similar studies in other organisms, contributing to a comparative understanding of bioelectricity in aging and disease, and potentially informing the development of electroceutical therapies for age-related conditions in humans.
chunks.chunk_summary: Future research should focus on the mechanisms of bioelectric patterns in hydra and their link to aging, using transgenic tools and comparative approaches to inform potential electroceutical therapies.
